title: Where's the Constitutional right to write exams?
text:
While I am fully supportive of the reasons for the current nationwide protest action against the exorbitant university fee increases proposed for 2016, I must question why current students - such as UCT's GDA students and probably thousands others - are not being allowed to exercise their constitutional (or would it be democratic)right to write their exams?
These students are all about to enter the job market - assuming all or most of them have accounting articles to go to in 2016 - and thus join the tiny South African tax-paying base, which largely funds the running of this country, including the higher education subsidies which are the prime subject of this dispute.
If these students are disrupted to the extent that they fail these exams, they will be excluded from this vital opportunity to swell the current number of tax-paying employed young people.
They undoubtedly support the principles of 'fees must fall' but surely they have rights too?
